comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: NYT of June 30, 1912 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40C17F935581373... talks about a saucer-shaped "stadium motordrome" opening in 1912 -- for motorcycle racing. It says nothing about being a remodeling of the horse track (although that was adapted to motor-racing). So this may be a completely different stadium. NYT of May 7, 1912 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50F16FA3E581373... indicates that the new track for motorcycling was a perfect circle, 1/3 mile in circumference.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Several newspaper articles indicates that it existed a Stadium motordrome at Brighton Beach, also called "Brighton Beach Stadium" at least since 1912. e.g. The sun., August 26, 1912, (chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1912-08-26/ed-...) New-York tribune., August 12, 1912, Page 8 (chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1912-08-12/ed-...) That must be the stadium shown in the photo (but it's unclear to me whether this stadium was built on the ground of the former horse racing facility).

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Yes, this is the Brighton Beach Motordrome, though it was also referred to by other names. Chances are, this is showing the arena prepared for boxing, as the ring is in the center and the interior of the track is blocked out in sections. It is probably being prepared for the September 11, 1915 fight between celelebrated middleweights Packy McFarland and Mike Gibbons. Here's a NYT article describing the upcoming bout: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B0DE3DD133FE233A... The New International Yearbook for 1915 said "The bout of the year which attracted the most interest in New York City was that between Mike Gibbons and Packey McFarland at Brighton Beach. The men battled to a draw before a $58,000 "gate." books.google.com/books?pg=PA95&lpg=PA95&dq=%22bri... Another Times article on the day of the fight gave further details, estimating a crowd of 40,000: select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0614F83A5C1373... It says the Motordrome is at the Brighton Beach Station of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Co. Here, the Bain picture is used in a story about preparing for the fight: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1915-08-22/ed-... New York Tribune, 8-22-15
